summary: The eighteenth data release (DR18) of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) marks the beginning of the fifth generation of the survey, known as SDSS-V. This release introduces three main scientific programs, referred to as 'Mappers,' which include the Milky Way Mapper (MWM), the Black Hole Mapper (BHM), and the Local Volume Mapper. DR18 provides extensive targeting information for the MWM and BHM programs, along with input catalogs and selection functions aimed at supporting various scientific objectives. The release also features approximately 25,000 new SDSS spectra and additional data related to X-ray sources identified by eROSITA in its eFEDS field. Furthermore, the authors discuss updates to the SDSS software pipelines and preview upcoming changes for the next data release, DR19. Additionally, they highlight three value-added catalogs based on SDSS-IV data published since the previous release and one based on SDSS-V data in the eFEDS field, indicating ongoing enhancements to the dataset.
reasoning: The summary encapsulates the main points of the abstract by outlining the significance of DR18 as the first release of SDSS-V, the introduction of the Mappers, and the detailed data provided. It emphasizes the new data, software updates, and value-added catalogs which collectively illustrate the progress and expansion of the SDSS project. This focus on the overarching themes rather than the specific methodologies allows for a clear understanding of the research's contributions.
